statements.text: The theft was discovered at 6:00 a.m. on Monday, March 3, when the cleaning staff arrived at the Marlowe Art Gallery.
A priceless painting, 'Twilight Over Venice,' had been cut from its frame.
Mr. Felix Marlowe, the owner of the gallery, was on a business trip in Tokyo at the time of the theft.
Surveillance footage showed the gallery's alarm system being deactivated at 2:13 a.m. on March 3.
Only three people knew the alarm code: Mr. Marlowe, the gallery manager, and the night guard.
The night guard, Isaac Webb, had signed out of his shift at 1:45 a.m., claiming a sudden illness.
Mr. Webb was later found unconscious in his apartment, claiming he had been drugged.
Traces of a powerful sedative were found in the coffee machine in the gallery's break room.
Ms. Chloe Brenner, the gallery manager, stated she had locked the gallery securely at 10:00 p.m. the previous night.
A local art dealer, Victor Prowse, was arrested three years ago for attempting to sell a forged Monet painting.
Witnesses reported seeing Mr. Prowse near the gallery late Sunday night, wearing a grey overcoat and carrying a black duffel bag.
A similar grey overcoat was found discarded in a trash bin behind Prowse's antique store.
Security logs showed that Chloe Brenner accessed the alarm system at 2:12 a.m., one minute before it was deactivated.
Mr. Marlowe's assistant confirmed he was attending a collector's conference in Tokyo with verified hotel and flight records.
The painting had been insured for $5 million, and Mr. Marlowe had recently increased the policy coverage.
Police recovered a high-quality forgery of 'Twilight Over Venice' in an abandoned van near the waterfront.
Forensic experts believe the forgery was created by the same person who forged the Monet painting three years ago.
Victor Prowse denied any involvement and said he was home alone watching television at the time.
No fingerprints were found on the forgery, but a single hair was recovered and sent for analysis.
The lab confirmed that the hair matched Isaac Webb.
